entry.title: SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting - Introducing New Rules for Automatic Postings
entry.content:
The new rules for automatic postings gradually replace existing functions such as net income calculations and reclassifications. These posting rules offer more capabilities, greater flexibility, and a modern user interface.

The following examples highlight the flexibility of the new rules:

  • Define source data flexibly, including field selections and period interval 
  • Assign multiple document types in one task
  • Include multiple posting lines
  • Define target data flexibly, including field assignment using attributes, and value calculation formula
  • Include results from previous rules
  • Use an enhanced partner filter for intra-unit eliminations.
  • Use the field assignment option 'Value Of ' to post on partner fields

-
Scenarios

With the rules for automatic postings, you can automate tasks such as:

  • Net income calculation for reported data while maintaining the same document type as the source data, and  also the original profit center or segment.
  • Reclassification of the inventory of finished goods to the inventory of semi-finished goods for manufacturing consolidation units.
  • Elimination of the inter-unit sales (reported by the selling consolidation unit) against the cost of sales in the partner unit (the buying consolidation unit).
  • Elimination of inter-unit receivables and payables against a balancing FS item to analyze the intercompany difference.
  • Elimination of intra-unit operations reported between different profit centers within one consolidation unit.

-
Components

Components

  1. When you run a task from the data or consolidation monitor, the system runs all the posting rules included in the rule group assigned to the task.
  2. Each rule selects source data and posts one or more posting lines. The rule automatically assigns the field values and calculates the amounts to post.
  3. The system creates a log that includes source lines, posting lines and any warning or error messages.

Use the following three new apps to manage the posting rules:

 

Rule Definition

Watch this video for guidance on defining a posting rule to calcule the net income:

 

Rule Type

You define a rule with one of the following rule types:

  • Net Income Calculation
  • Postings for Consolidation Units
  • Postings for Consolidation Unit Pairs

The type determines which options are available or required. The rule type also determines the monitor (Data Monitor, Consolidation Monitor) where the rules can be carried out.

Examples: 

  • A posting rule that was defined with rule type Postings for Consolidation Unit Pairs requires the Partner Units filter, and can be assigned to a task only in the Consolidation Monitor.
  • The option Post on Original Document Type is available only for the rule type Net Income Calculation.

Source Data

In this section, you define how the rule selects data. You can use:

  • A Selection defined in the Define Selections app.
  • A Period Selection, such as Year to Date, Prior Period, or Opening Balances.
  • Specific fields to include or exclude when reading data. Excluded fields are aggregated, improving the performance and the readibility of the log. 

Note: The values for Period, Year, Version, Consolidation Unit aren't aggregated.

Example: Only the fields Profit Center and Segment are read in the screenshot below. Details of other fields such as Cost Center aren't retained, and source values are aggregated.

  • You use the "Partner Units" option for elimination rules. In most scenarios you select the option "Partners in the Consolidation Group" . If the source data doesn't include a Partner Unit, you can select "All Partners (including empty)".

Example: Use this option to eliminate business operations between profit centers within a single Consolidation Unit, where there is no partner unit breakdown.

 

Target Data

In this section you define the measures (local currency, transaction currency, group currency, quantity) and document types for the postings. The available document types depend on the rule type. 

By selecting the document type in the rule you can group multiple automatic postings with different document types into a single task. This approach reduces the number of tasks you need to manage.

Example: You can define different rules for inter unit eliminations, such as sales and cost of sales, receivables and payables, or dividends. You can then group these rules into one single task and then post on different document types .

Posting Lines

Each rule must include at least one posting line, and can include multiple ones. To create a balanced posting, you need at least two posting lines. The number of posting lines doesn't determine the number of line items that will be posted. The number of line items depends on the granularity of the source data.

Example: If you define a rule with two posting lines to eliminate the internal sales FS item (posting line 1) against the cost of sales FS item (posting line 2), and your source data is broken down by segment and profit center, it include many lines. The rule will post for two posting lines for each source line.

Overview

In this overview you can create, display, delete, and sort posting lines.

Posting lines define how the source data is adjusted before posting. You can for instance assign a specific FS Item, clear the Material Number, or post to the Partner Unit.

Note: The posting line number is displayed in the log that is created when you run the task. This helps you to easily relate the posting line in the rule definition to the log entry.

Field Assignments

There are different ways to change the field values depending on the field. For FS items, you can assign values using attributes such as role and target attributes.  You can also select or clear a value, or post to the corresponding partner field. If you don't define a specific assignment for a field, the source value is kept.

In the example below the rule swaps the unit and partner fields for consolidation unit and profit center, assigns the functional area YB18 only when it is empty in the source data, and posts the FS item that is the target elimination of the source FS item.

Value Calculation

The value calculation determines the value to post on the measures selected for the target data.

You can use the following:

  • Mathematical operators: + - / * ( ) 
  • Constants: A number
  • Variables: Keyword SOURCE for the source amounts

Rule group

Watch this video to learn how to define a rule group:

 

In a rule group you select the rules to be carried out when you run the automatic postings task.

You can create nodes and subnodes to organize the rule group. For example:

  • Rules for net income calculation and reclassification of inventory of finished goods

 

  • Rules for inter-unit eliminations

 

 

In some scenarios you need to define that one rule "Depends on Previous Rules". This is necessary when the source data for the current rule includes data posted by the previous rule. When you select this option, the system updates the sequence column to show the order of processing.

Assign Rule Group

Once the rule group is defined with all the rules, assign it to the task using the app Assign Rule Groups for Automatic Postings.

You can define this assignment on several criteria:

  • Version: Depending on the configuration of the versions, the assignment can be valid for multiple versions. For example you can define an elimination task that carries out only the profit and loss eliminations for the planning versions, and all eliminations for actuals versions.
  • Time: Valid from Period / Year
  • Consolidation Units: For automatic postings tasks in the data monitor, you can restrict the assignment to selected consolidation units
  • Periods: you can restrict the assignment to certain periods. This allows one task to carry out different rule groups for a monthly (periods 1-11) or for a yearly consolidation (period 12).

Automatic Postings Run and Log

Watch this video to learn how to run a task for automatic postings and display the log:

 

You can change the log layout by selecting fields to display, and by defining grouping and sorting options.

The following fields help you analyze the log:

  • Item Type: Indicates whether the line is a source line or a posting line
  • Rule: The name of the rule that created the automatic posting
  • Posted Line: The number of the posting line defined in the rule
  • Source amounts and Posted amounts

-

More Information

Rules for Automatic Postings 

Automatic Postings in Data Monitor 

Automatic Postings in Consolidation Monitor 

-

Features by Release

entry.title: Do We Need a Separate Company Code for Hungarian Subsidiary?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I’m looking for some guidance on company code setup across countries and would love your expert input.

We have the following scenario:

  • A German company code exists and is fully operational.

  • The organization also has a subsidiary in Hungary.

  • We want to understand whether it’s mandatory to create a separate Hungarian company code in SAP, or whether we could run everything under the existing German company code.

Specifically, we’re considering two scenarios:

  1. Hungarian Legal Entity Exists

    • There is a registered Hungarian subsidiary (legal entity).

    • Can we still process sales and purchasing in Hungary under the German company code, or is it mandatory to create a separate Hungarian company code for local compliance, reporting, and taxes?

  2. No Hungarian Legal Entity Exists

    • The German company is doing business in Hungary directly (cross-border) without a registered Hungarian entity.

    • In this case, is it acceptable to use the German company code in SAP, provided we handle Hungarian VAT registration and tax obligations separately?

Our goal is to stay compliant while avoiding unnecessary complexity in SAP if it’s not required.

I’d really appreciate hearing from those who’ve implemented similar cross-border setups:

  • How did you handle statutory reporting and tax compliance?

  • Any pitfalls or lessons learned?

  • Best practices you’d recommend?

Thank you in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Peppol Participant Registration for Belgian Companies
entry.content:
As of January 1, 2026, Belgian companies are required to exchange electronic invoices that are compliant with the European semantic and syntactic standard (EN 16931) with their business partners. The Peppol network is the secure network for this exchange, and companies need to register a participant for their company in this network. If you’re facing the task of registering your company in the Peppol network, this blog provides you with simple tips and guidance.

For more information about the Belgian legal change, see the Regulatory Change Manager or this blog Get Ready for the Mandatory Shift to E-invoicing in Belgium – The Clock is Ticking.

 

How Belgian companies should register

The Belgian Peppol authority, BOSA (FOD Beleid en Ondersteuning - SPF Stratégie & Appui), has defined Peppol Authority Specific Requirements (PASR) for its area of application, according to which companies must first and at least register as a participant in the Peppol network using their company number provided by the Belgian Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (CBE). After this initial registration, companies can register more participants using the VAT number or other identifiers, such as a SWIFT code or a GLN.

The steps are as follows:

Step 1: Mandatory registration:

First, register your company as a participant in the Peppol network using your company number with party ID type "0208".

0208: This party ID type represents the Belgian Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (CBE), which assigns unique party IDs for companies operating in Belgium, for example: 0441797980.

Here are the detailed steps on how to create a participant in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: Creating a Participant for Your Company.

This creates a participant ID in the Peppol network consisting of the party ID type (it should be 0208 if it is your first participant) and the actual party ID for your company. As you can see, this participant ID is not given in advance by a government agency such as Peppol or a Peppol Access Point (AP) such as SAP.

Don’t forget to also register your company to receive electronic invoices: Registering Your Company to Receive Electronic Documents in the Peppol Network.

If your participant only exists in the Peppol network but is not yet registered to receive documents, you can send electronic documents through the Peppol network but can’t receive any.

Step 2: (Optional) additional registration:

In addition, you can register your company in the Peppol network using the company's VAT number, for example: BE0441797980, with the party ID type "9925". Other alternatives for the registration are the use of the generic ID ”0088” referring to the GLN or any other valid Peppol participant ID.

 

Migration from Hermes required

Hermes was an initiative by the Belgian government to advance electronic invoicing by enabling the receiving of electronic invoices in PDF format for receivers who are not (yet) able to process XML files.

All Belgian companies with a Belgian company number (party ID type: 0208) have been included by BOSA in the Hermes SMP (Service Metadata Publisher), which is part of the Peppol network.

If your company is ready to receive XML files, you must register your company using a Peppol Access Point like the cloud edition. However, if your company number is already used in Hermes SMP, your Peppol service provider needs to migrate it to the SMP of the Peppol Access Point. After this migration, you can then register your company number in the Peppol network as described in the previous section.

Support for SAP customers

If you are using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition as Peppol service provider, SAP migrates your company number for you from Hermes SMP to the SMP of SAP. To initiate the migration, create a customer case in SAP for Me with the title "MTCI migration required by Hermes SMP" under the component "LOD-LH-DRC-PAP". For other concerns regarding the electronic invoicing process, you can also submit a customer case under the component “CA-GTF-CSC-EDO-BE”.

 

 

I hope this blog was useful for you! You can leave a comment here or continue browsing our community for more blogs on SAP Document and Reporting Compliance topics.

entry.title: How SAP’s ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App Simplifies Multi-Tenant Side-by-Side Extensions on BTP
entry.content:
The SAP BTP ABAP environment continues to open powerful opportunities for partners and developers who want to extend and integrate with  SAP Cloud ERP - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. To simplify this process, SAP provides an open-source reference: the ABAP Partner Reference Application.

The SAP-Samples Git repository demonstrates how to design, build, and operate multi-tenant side-by-side applications using ABAP Cloud practices while following SAP’s recommended development approaches. The ABAP Partner Reference Application provides developers and technical architects with standard patterns, modular code, and documented guidance for building robust, multi-tenant ABAP applications on SAP BTP, fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It guides partners on designing, deploying, and extending ABAP solutions. It provides a blueprint for building scalable, multi-tenant apps that extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

What is the ABAP Partner Reference Application?

The ABAP Partner Reference Application (APRA) is a sample implementation that provides practical examples, such as the Music Festival Manager. It shows partners how to:

  • Build extensions on SAP BTP ABAP Cloud.
  • Integrate seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Handle critical multi-tenant aspects such as tenant provisioning, onboarding, and isolation.
  • Follow SAP’s ABAP Cloud and Restful ABAP Programming Model (RAP) guidelines.

In short, it’s a real-world blueprint for partners who need a reference starting point.

Key Capabilities Highlighted

  • Multi-tenancy design: APRA showcases how to build applications that serve multiple tenants securely while keeping data isolated.
  • Tenant lifecycle management: Includes practical examples of provisioning and onboarding processes.
  • Integration patterns: Demonstrates how ABAP applications can consume SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs side by side, extending core business logic without modification.
  • Best practices in ABAP Cloud: Clean-core extensions, RAP-based services, and modular design patterns are applied throughout

Why It Matters for Partners

For partners building SAP-certified solutions, alignment with ABAP Cloud principles is no longer optional. APRA offers more than just example code: it provides implementation guidance to ensure solutions are cloud-ready, scalable, and compliant. By studying and adapting the repository, partners save time, reduce uncertainty, and can fast-track their certification and deployment processes.

  • The repository demonstrates and aligns with SAP clean-core architecture and RAP best practices, enabling maintainable, upgrade-safe solutions. Along with modularization, helping partners build solutions that are scalable, maintainable, and compliant with SAP’s cloud-first best practices.
  • It provides real-world samples for rapid development of side-by-side extensions in the SAP BTP ABAP environment.
  • It demonstrates end-to-end flows: business object modelling, onboarding and provisioning, secure multi-tenancy, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API integration. It includes example business objects, tenant-specific onboarding logic, and detailed sample integrations with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, serving as ready-to-adapt templates for real-world enterprise scenarios.
  • Each step—from tenant lifecycle management to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality using side-by-side applications—is implemented with guidance notes and sample ABAP artifacts, making cloud development approachable for teams at any skill level.
  • Multi-Tenancy Patterns: Learn how to isolate data and processes by tenant, automate provisioning, and secure user access using SAP BTP role collections and dedicated onboarding flows.
  • Integration Points: Discover how to consume core APIs, events, and data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition while preserving ERP clean core, using recommended SAP BTP services for authentication, navigation, and extensibility.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud Usage: Access sample RAP service definitions and back-end logic that illustrate SAP’s latest cloud-based application paradigms, making it straightforward to adopt modern development models.

 Getting Started / How to Use the Repository

The repository is publicly available on GitHub and welcomes exploration. Developers can:

  • Clone the GIT repository, browse the artifacts, and review the README for instructions on deployment and configuration. Clone the main branch to start with ready-to-run examples or tutorials.
  • Follow the incremental development guides in the main branch to build up your own ABAP partner app using the same best practices. Follow examples for multi-tenant design, onboarding, and integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Analyze business object definitions, RAP service implementations, and onboarding/integration logic to adapt for your own solution. Use the sample reference application as templates for partner apps, adapting the RAP artifacts and onboarding logic for your business scenario and leverage the documented guidance to use APRA as a starting template for your own solutions.

Inside the Repository: Packages and Artifacts

  • The repository is organized to guide developers through building a core ABAP application, then evolving it into a multi-tenant solution.
  • Artifacts are grouped by application logic (business objects), onboarding flows, integration APIs, and service definitions that illustrate SAP’s recommended RAP approach.
  • The samples Music Festival Manager and Poetry Slam Manager demonstrate business object modeling, UI integration, and tenant isolation in real-world use cases.

 How the Repository Accelerates Partner Solutions

  • Partners can reuse packages, study onboarding approaches, and adapt integration modules directly for their own certified offerings—streamlining time to market and improving solution quality.
  • Step-by-step documentation, real code, and sample data flows empower developers to master multi-tenant patterns and extend SAP Cloud systems with confidence.
  • The repository acts as a knowledge base and starter kit for enterprise ABAP cloud projects, bridging theory and practical implementation for SAP’s partner ecosystem.

By exploring this repository, developers and architects gain hands-on experience with the foundations of multi-tenant architecture, SAP BTP-managed security, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integration—directly addressing the needs of modern cloud-native SAP applications.

For partners, the repository turns cloud-native theory into practice. Get hands on with SAP BTP ABAP Cloud, accelerate certified solution development, and leverage proven patterns for multi-tenant extensions—all with guided help from SAP’s own reference implementation.

entry.title: Build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology
entry.content:
What is SAP BTP Guidance Framework: The Guidance Framework provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. With this guidance, you can develop intelligent applications using advanced analytics, equipping your organization with a robust foundation to support agile innovation. For more details read this blog. 

In this blog post, we will look into how to build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. You can find this Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology pillar under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. 

It’s imperative that in today’s economy, data is more than just numbers—it’s the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. Yet many organizations still struggle to unlock the full potential of their data and give it purpose. SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 

  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities. 

2. Business Outcomes & Solution Requirements: the focus in this phase shifts to aligning data with measurable business goals such as:  

  • Define specific, data-driven business outcomes. 
  • Analyze use cases that trace how raw data transforms into business value. 
  • Identify required data products and map end-to-end integration flows. 

This phase allows to clearly define business outcome definitions and solution context diagrams. 

 3. Capability Map & Solution Architecture: this phase transforms requirements into a target architecture by: 

  • Developing a capability map using SAP BTP Maturity Assessment 
  • Explore architecture options through traditional capability mapping or solution diagrams from the SAP Discovery Center. 
  • Validate the preferred architecture with proof-of-concepts. 

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 4. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 

  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that it’s not just about technology—it’s about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives aren’t just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmap—it delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it. 

To read more about SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology check out SAP Discovery Center. 

“Organizations that adopt this framework position themselves to lead in the AI-driven economy” 

Previous blogs in the series:

  • SAP BTP AI Best Practices: Your Ultimate Guide for Building AI Solutions
  • SAP Discovery Center Expands and Welcomes the SAP BTP Guidance Framework
  • SAP BTP Developer’s Guide: Essential Best Practices from Setup to Scale
  • Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4

Stay tuned for the next blog post in our ‘Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework’ series! 
SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Business Data Cloud RISE with SAP SAP Business Suite Data Management

entry.title: Re: In S/4HANA Public Cloud, what is the cds view that co...
entry.content:
Hello @Joey3 ,

1. There is released CDS view or API for cost element category within the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Therefore, it is not possible to rely on the existing CDS view to create custom logic. If the requirement is mandatory, please consider to use GL account type + GL Account or some other fields to create your custom logic.

2. The K_ACCOUNT_ASSIGNMENT_GET related to the SSCUI "Default account assignment", there is no existing CDS view for this customizing. The customizing data can be retrieved from the customizing directly.

It is recommended to check whether the requirement from business point of view can have some workaround with some other fields or use custom business object if required.

Kind Regards,

entry.title: About Line Item Validation
entry.content:
Hi all,
I"d like to know more about line item validation performed in the data monitor.

1. What data table is being checked?
The help documentation for the configuration activity states, "Accounting: Checks line items from accounting table ACDOCA."

However, the Help Portal states, "Run line item validation to check if errors exist on posting level blank and 0C."
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/90c07e91c7a64f328be3fd6b48955b13/b3ab8186216b4e729f6901069dc6c96b.html?locale=en-US

Does the "posting level blank and 0C" statement mean that the data table being checked is ACDOCU, not ACDOCA?

2. Regarding validation rules
The Help Portal states, "This task or tasks identify any errors or warnings from validation rules. These rules have the business context GR Journal Entry Item and are maintained in the Manage Substitution/Validation Rules - Group Journal Entries app."

However, even after adding validation rules, they don"t work with Line Item Validation.
Why is this?
(The added validation rules work when entering group journal entries.)
(Validation rule: AmountInLocalCurrency=10)

entry.title: SAP Adoption PDF Report generator in Customer Insights (in SAP for Me)
entry.content:
We would like to provide details about the SAP Adoption Report. You can access it from SAP for Me  in section Reporting or clicking here. SAP Adoption Report is a downloadable PDF report that provides comprehensive. view of license usage, functional adoption, and business value realization, enabling data-driven decisions for digital transformation and cost efficiency.  

The report is organized into four key sections:

1. Customer Factsheet

This section provides a comprehensive snapshot of the customer’s organizational profile, and their SAP purchased portfolio. This factsheet enables customers and SAP teams to quickly understand the current solution landscape, identify expiring contracts, and ensure alignment with business needs. It also supports offline sharing and documentation for internal or external stakeholders.

  • Basic Company Information: Name, customer number, region, country, industry, and partner status.
  • Contractual Details: Support contracts, premium engagements, SAP customer since, SAP cloud customer since.
  • Purchased Solutions: A detailed list of all SAP solutions currently licensed, segmented by product group and solution area.
  • Upcoming Renewals: Highlights any solutions with renewals due in the next two quarters from the date of reporting, helping customers proactively manage their subscriptions.

 

2. License Consumption Analysis

This section delivers a granular view of how SAP licenses are being utilized. This analysis helps customers optimize their license usage, avoid compliance risks, and identify opportunities for cost savings or further adoption. It also supports SAP’s goal of scaling support and driving adoption through self-service reporting.

  • Consumption Levels: Breaks down licenses into underused (<20%), regularly used (20–100%), and overconsumed (>100%) categories, both overall and by solution area.
  • Trend Analysis: Visualizes consumption trends over time, helping to spot patterns such as increasing adoption, persistent underutilization, or risk of overconsumption. 

 

3. Functional Usage & Industry Benchmarking

This section evaluates how deeply and broadly SAP solution capabilities are being used over time. This benchmarking enables identify gaps in adoption, prioritize enablement efforts, and unlock additional value. It also enables SAP and partners to target support and improvement initiatives more effectively.

  • Usage Intensity: Tracks how intensely (based on actual system traffic) each solution capabilities are being used per solution area.

 

  • Trends: Shows how functional usage evolves over time, both in total and by product group. 

  • Industry Comparison: Benchmarks the customer’s usage against industry peers, highlighting capabilities that are widely adopted in the industry but underutilized by the customer. 

 

4. Business Value Realization

This section maps the tangible business outcomes achieved through SAP solutions, helping customers and SAP teams assess the ROI of their SAP investments, document achievements for internal/external reporting, and prioritize future initiatives to maximize business impact. The PDF format allows for snapshot tracking overtime

  • Value Realization Overview: Shows the percentage of business values realized in each solution area, based on the number of solution capabilities in use. 

  • Detailed Value Mapping: Lists all business values (e.g., cost reduction, productivity gains, risk mitigation) for each solution area, and highlights which are realized, and which remain unrealized.


  • Unrealized Value Analysis: Identifies specific solution capabilities and value drivers that have not yet been achieved, providing actionable insights for further adoption or process improvement.

Benefits and Future Enhancements

The generated report provides a static snapshot of the current situation, complementing the regularly updated dashboard data. You can use these tools for reporting and collaboration with SAP support and the SAP front-office teams.

We welcome your feedback and suggestions for further report automation and additional reports.

Please use the ‘Feedback’ menu in the left edge of the page to share with us your feedback on this new tool and help us to improve the reporting functionality in SAP for Me.

Stay updated by subscribing to this blog and visiting the SAP Support Portal / Customer Insights.

SAP for Me is made for you!

Related blogs: SAP for Me goes reporting  or all related blogs to ‘Customer Insights’ reporting dashboard.

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at KBA 3580792 & Manage Business Partner Master Data for more details.

To summarise, yes, the migration of contact persons is indeed limited in the public cloud. If you use the customer migration object in the cockpit and fill the contacts section, the system will always create new contact person BPs even if the same contact is linked to other business partners.

There is currently no standard mass maintenance app that allow you to later merge or link your contact persons across various BPs.

I suggest you use the manage business partner master data to migrate contact persons as a separate business partners, then link existing contact person to multiple business partner.

If this process is too manual, you may consider submitting influence request to SAP.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP BTP Guidance Framework: Center of Expertise (CoE), Administration and DevOps
entry.content:
As outlined in the blog post SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators from Cecily Sorenson (@cecilysorenson), the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a practical framework for anyone using SAP BTP. In this blog post, let's focus especially on the organizational setup and the role and tasks of an administrator. 

Overview of SAP BTP Guidance Framework - and focus of this blog post

Here, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework brings a lot to get you started! 

 

Organizational Setup 

One main question faced in almost every SAP BTP project is on the best organizational setup to ease a smooth onboarding, reduce time to value and to operate the platform effectively. One key aspect can be the founding of a central platform engineering team or a Center of Expertise (CoE) that is responsible for such topics as account operations, infrastructure, central governance and compliance - and for driving the overall cloud adoption across the organization. 

A CoE can make the difference and help your cloud development teams to transition towards a cloud-centric mindset and processes, as the provided guidance allows them to focus more on providing business value without having to bother about finding, implementing and running the right infrastructure and processes. 

Therefore, it should be no surprise that the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers guidance here as well, in the form of the SAP BTP Center of Expertise (CoE) Guide. 

The guide provides a comprehensive framework for establishing and scaling an SAP BTP CoE. For example, it gives a definition of a CoE, outlines a corresponding maturity model, explains roles and responsibilities, and gives practical guidance on how to implement it along the lifecycle. 

Overview of maturity model explained in the SAP BTP CoE Guide

 

Administrating the Platform and the Lifecycle 

To learn more about actual tasks and responsibilities for administrating the platform itself and for handling the lifecycle of your applications and use cases running on it, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers the SAP BTP Administrator's Guide. 

Understand basic concepts and tasks, before benefitting from guidance and best practices along topics such as: 

  • Your account model 
  • Delivering your applications and changes towards your runtime with the right mix of agility and control 
  • Operating your applications on SAP BTP, with a combination of central observability (to get aware of how your business scenarios are behaving) and local observability tools for root cause analysis in case of issues or performance degradations 

This also comprises check lists, examples and guidance. For example, here’s an example for an individual account model: 

Picture of an exemplary account model for SAP BTP

 

DevOps with SAP BTP 

When transitioning to the cloud, you want to benefit from modern development principles in the spirit of DevOps. But how does this fit to stricter boundary conditions faced in an enterprise environment? 

Here, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework also has you covered - by offering a description how to enable your development teams to benefit from tight feedback loops offered by automated build and test pipelines ("Continuous Integration") in combination with the right level of control for the delivery towards production. 

Overview of DevOps approach with SAP BTP

For this, your development teams can use pipeline templates to set up a running build and test pipeline for typical SAP BTP development use cases - thanks to our opinionated "Pipeline-as-a-Service" approach, they can set them up in minutes and run them with crucially reduced cognitive load. These pipelines then can qualify the development changes in terms of provided functionality, usage of outdated libraries, code issues, and other compliance-relevant aspects, as needed by your business. 

As soon as your development teams come up with correspondingly qualified release candidates, they can easily switch on in the pipeline the automated handover of the changes into a central, reliable transport and change management approach. Here, your administration team can centrally define delivery landscapes, including permissions on who is allowed to come up and handle changes where and a central log file for auditing reasons. This can be decoupled from the development teams who only need to know the entry node to the delivery, using a clearly defined hand-over process from qualified agile development into controlled delivery towards production.  

With a simple integration of transport management into SAP's central operation platforms, this can even be extended to central change management processes, to handle interdependencies of changes from different environments by centrally orchestrating their propagation across SAP BTP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP cloud solutions. All this can be enriched with additional release planning and management capabilities. 

 

Summary 

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework has a lot to offer also for administrators – from a framework to forge your organizational setup to guidance on how to handle the lifecycle of your applications and use cases on SAP BTP and on how to combine agile development with the right level of control over changes in your runtime environment. 

If you should have feedback on the documents and offerings mentioned above, please let us know – ideally by providing feedback in SAP Help Portal, as described for example here: SAP BTP Documentation Goes GitHub - New Collaborat... - SAP Community

Hello @skalaivanan. There is simply a method like this inside the behavior implementation

  METHOD dequeue_object.

    CASE class_type.
      WHEN '002'. "Equipment class
        CALL FUNCTION 'DEQUEUE_EIEQUI'
          EXPORTING
            mode_equi = 'E'
*           mandt     = SY-MANDT
            equnr     = CONV equnr( object_key )
*           x_equnr   = space
*           _scope    = '3'
*           _synchron = space
*           _collect  = ' '
          .
    ENDCASE.
  ENDMETHOD.

This gets called in SAVE_MODIFIED like this

METHOD save_modified.

    IF create-object IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT create-object INTO DATA(class_object).
        " whatever you need to do

        " dequeue record to prevent self-locking
        lhc_object=>dequeue_object( object_key = class_object-ClfnObjectID class_type = class_object-ClassType ).
        " try to save but no commit
        classification_object->save( abap_false ).

* NOT ALLOWED TO CATCH ERRORS. No errors allowed at this point
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.

....

entry.title: Everyday issues: Unmanaged SAP HANA database backup.
entry.content:
last updated: 2025-09-22

Table of Content

  1. Why was this blog post created?
  2. How to check/detect if SAP HANA is having an unmanaged database backup issue?
  3. What is the conclusion?
  4. Everyday issues
  5. Other article
  6. Useful bookmark

Why was this blog post created?
Unmanaged SAP HANA database backup can affect overall system performance (such as, general performance, memory area, CPU usage, and so on). Properly configuring SAP HANA database backup is an essential task. Missing this task can cause various issues (which are sometimes very difficult to identify precisely).

How to check/detect if SAP HANA is having an unmanaged database backup issue?

1. 3284834 - SQL Statement Collection: "HANA_Configuration_Minichecks" report for SAP HANA

The most general report will contain further information about the issue. The minicheck report contains a dedicated section belongs to backup area. With this report we can easily identify if there is issue with the backup. In the below example the Size of backup catalog (MB) and Age of oldest backup in catalog (days) values shows there are issue.

195;**** ;BACKUP                                         ;        ;                                              ;              ; ;        
196;     ;                                               ;        ;                                              ;              ; ;        
197;  910;Age of last data backup (days)                 ;        ;0.37                                          ;<= 1.20       ; ; 1642148
198;  911;Age of last data backup error (days)           ;        ;2394.37                                       ;>= 1.20       ; ; 1642148
199;  915;Min. data backup throughput (GB/h, last week)  ;        ;3583.67                                       ;>= 200.00     ; ; 1999930
200;  916;Avg. data backup throughput (GB/h, last week)  ;        ;3810.26                                       ;>= 300.00     ; ; 1999930
201;  920;Age of last log backup (hours)                 ;        ;0.12                                          ;<= 1.00       ; ; 1642148
202;  921;Age of last log backup error (days)            ;        ;1657.16                                       ;>= 1.00       ; ; 1642148
203;  922;Maximum log backup duration (s, last day)      ;        ;140                                           ;<= 300        ; ; 2063454
204;  923;Log backup errors (last month)                 ;        ;0                                             ;<= 10         ; ; 1642148
205;  930;Automatic log backup                           ;        ;yes                                           ;yes           ; ; 1645183
206;  935;Database log mode                              ;        ;normal                                        ;normal        ; ; 1645183
207;  940;Size of backup catalog (MB)                    ;        ;463.63                                        ;<= 50.00      ;X; 2505218
208;  942;Catalog size share (last day, %)               ;        ;12.43                                         ;<= 3.00       ;X; 2505218
209;  945;Age of oldest backup in catalog (days)         ;        ;2532                                          ;<= 100        ;X; 2505218
210;  950;Log segments not free for reuse                ;        ;3                                             ;<= 100        ; ;        
211;  952;Log segments free for reuse                    ;        ;22                                            ;<= 250        ; ;        
212;  955;Max. number of log backups / service (last day);        ;650                                           ;<= 300        ;X;

2. 3411878 - Backup related Housekeeping - LEAD SAP Note and 3339034 - SAP HANA multiple issue (Alert ID: 2, 36, 65) caused by large Log Backups due to large Backup Catalog size

The SAP Knowledge Base Articles contains all relevant information to investigate further and the resolution steps.

What is the conclusion?
The best option to setup the proper backup right after the installation of SAP HANA. Retention period needs to choose correctly and the backup activity needs to review periodically. If initial actions missed, right after the backup related issue identified it needs to be solved, so the related issues will be eliminated. 

Everyday issues
✍️ Everyday issues: There is no miracle or magic. SAP HANA database needs memory.

Other article
✍️ Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?

Useful bookmark
🔖 2872774 – Bookmark of Frequently Asked Questions for SAP HANA
🔖 3311408 – Bookmark of SQL Statement Collection reports for SAP HANA
🔖 2658020 – List of SAP HANA SQL Error Codes

Do you have further questions?
Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
Q&A link for SAP HANA: https://answers.sap.com/tags/73554900100700000996 

Contribution
If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

Release DateDescription
2025.09.22First/initial Release of the SAP Blog Post documentation (Technical Article).

entry.title: Reporting in SAP for Me: New tabs "Survey (New)" and "Survey (Old)" in the Case reporting
entry.content:
Overview of Support Survey Improvements

Starting April 1st, 2025, the SIS Survey has been redesigned to enhance user experience and data quality. The updated version now features fewer, more relevant questions presented in a single-page format, making it quicker and more straightforward to complete. Unnecessary items have been removed, and some drivers have been simplified. These changes are intended to provide more focused and valuable insights while making the survey process more efficient.

New Reporting Tabs in SAP for ME

With the introduction of the new survey, we have updated the reporting section in SAP for ME (in Cases) to support this transition. You will now find two distinct tabs:

  • Survey (Old): Displays data collected using the previous survey format before April 1st, 2025.
  • Survey (New): Shows responses submitted through the updated survey.

This separation allows for clear comparison of results before and after the changes, providing transparency and supporting your reporting needs.

Tab Survey (Old):

In this tab you will see the different metrics that were part of the old version of the survey:

  • Customer Effort and Correct Solution 
  • Expertise and Professionalism
  • Timely Solution and Updates
  • Product Satisfaction

Tab Survey (New)

In this tab you can find at the moment the rating of Customer Rating (SAP Made it Easy), but it is planned to enhance this reporting with the new information coming from the new version survey. 

Contact and Feedback

If you have any questions or require further information, please add your comments below or contact us directly. Your feedback is important as we continue to improve the Reporting section in SAP for ME.

Stay updated by subscribing to this blog and visiting the SAP Support Portal / Customer Insights.

SAP for Me is made for you!

Related blogs: SAP for Me goes reporting  or all related blogs to ‘Customer Insights’ reporting dashboard.

entry.title: Re: SAP Business One
entry.content:
Hi,

SAP Business One and S/4 are two completely different systems. HANA is a database system that is used with both.

If you plan to become an S/4 consultant, experience with SAP Business One is mostly useless. Except if SAP Business One is running on HANA. In that case you can you get good experience with HANA first.

SAP Business One contains all modules to run a (small to medium) business. S/4 is a collection of modules, that reflects the customer's needs. When a customer uses S/4, they can take more modules into use later on.

To determine which S/4 module(s) you should specialize in, take a look at what part(s) of SAP Business One you enjoy using most.

Regards,

Johan

entry.title: Re: SAC Advanced Formula Calculate with first of each month
entry.content:
@Franziska3 

As you mentioned FIRST returns First day of Year and not each month. One way to look at the problem is that you are always N-1 days away from first Day at a any given date. So on 10th of a month you are 9 days away from 1st. Applying that principle to the logic.

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Funktionsbereich] , [d/Sachkonto], [d/Kostenart], [d/Kunde],[d/CCW_Material], [d/Vertriebsweg], [d/Buchungskreis], [d/Profitcenter], [d/Sparte],[d/Verkaufsorganisation]

INTEGER @Day // Variable to store day-1
VARIABLEMEMBER #MENGE OF [d/Measures]

DATA([d/Measures] = #MENGE, [d/Funktionsbereich] = "#", [d/Sachkonto] = "#", [d/Profitcenter] = "#", [d/Sparte] = "#", [d/Kostenart] = "#") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Menge_ST")
// Herstellkosten = Menge * Materialkosten
IF [d/Funktionsbereich] = BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0100") 
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0120")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0110")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0300")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0301")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0140")
	OR [d/Funktionsbereich] =BASEMEMBER([d/Funktionsbereich] , "Z0130")
THEN

FOREACH [d/Datum]
@Day=DAY([d/Datum])-1  // Get Day -1

	DELETE([d/Measures] = "Umsatz")
	DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz", [d/Kostenart]= "#") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = #MENGE, [d/Funktionsbereich] = "#", [d/Sachkonto] = "#", [d/Kostenart] = "#")
	* RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Preis", [d/Kunde] = "#", [d/Datum] = PREVIOUS(@Day,[d/Datum]), [d/Profitcenter] = "#", [d/Sparte] = "#",[d/Sachkonto] = "#")*-1
	ENDFOR
ENDIF

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

entry.title: Enhancement Request: Duplicate Workflow Approvers
entry.content:
Please vote. 

Our company has a robust workflow approval process that often includes multiple layers of leadership—VP, SVP, EVP—as well as HR Business Partners. In some cases, the same individual may appear in multiple approval roles (e.g., as both the direct manager and the VP), resulting in redundant approvals for the same position change.

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/356979

Proposal: Enhance the workflow logic to detect when an approver is already included in a previous step of the approval chain and automatically skip duplicate approvals for that individual.

Example Scenario:
A salaried position change requires approvals from:

  • Manager
  • Manager +1
  • VP
  • Executive
  • HRBP

If Adam is both the Manager and the VP, and Veronica is both Manager +1 and the Executive approver, the system should recognize these overlaps and skip redundant approvals.

        <included_at> <http://example.org/hotels/LongIsland>. 
    } 
    }
    ', '', ?, ?
);

, I get following error:
Could not execute 'CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE(' INSERT DATA { GRAPH <kg_hotels> { ...'
Error: (dberror) [129]: transaction rolled back by an internal error: generic Error - check_ready_for_request: Startup error - Triple Store cannot handle request. exception 335110: generic. Error - /0/snap-4.5_1/manifest: Missing file - Manifest file does not exist

I get this error with any query that uses the Knowledge Graph Engine.

I figured it might be because the Triple Store feature wasn't activated properly. I manually restarted the HANA instance in addition to the default restart that occurs when the feature is activated. This made no difference in the behavior.

 

Does anyone understand this error or know how to resolve it? Can anyone help me with the issue? I would be immensely grateful! Thank you very much.

 

Kind regards
Joshua

entry.title: Using mathematical instead of artificial intelligence in the ABAP environments for 2508
entry.content:
1. Introduction

 
Do all intelligent ABAP apps use AI? 
 
Although using AI for all intelligent functionality is tempting, other techniques exist to gain insight. One of these is statistics. In contrast to AI, statistics is a mathematically sound science that will not produce fake answers and hallucinations but merely hard facts. These hard facts can then be used for operational decisions. I will call this mathematical, not artificial intelligence. 
 
Of course, there are new technologies like BDC  for data warehousing. However, having statistics available in your transactional ABAP applications might also be of great value, as many transactional decisions might be driven by a dataset already available in ABAP.
 
However, some foundations must be built to integrate statistical functions directly into the ABAP language. This blog post outlines these foundations and covers the integration of some new mathematical functions into the ABAP language in the ABAP environments for 2508.

For a concrete example of applying these functions, see the following blog post, where these are used to compute random numbers or quantiles using a C1 released cloud API.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/random-numbers-and-probability-distributions-in-the-abap-environments-for/ba-p/14173266

The now integrated functions are also part of an agenda to bring more built-in Python or Microsoft Excel functions into ABAP. A business analyst is expected to prepare a functionality in an Excel workspace or a Python script. Later on, this can be integrated into an ABAP app. 

Note: This is currently planned to be available on-premise and in the private cloud with the upcoming major SAP S/4HANA release in 2025. Please note that this plan is subject to change by SAP without prior notice.

2. Let's talk about data types

 
When discussing mathematical functions in ABAP, we have to talk about datatypes. For statistics, the computation must be fast. At the end, we will often calculate a percentage or some other number where only the first two decimal places are relevant. 
Implementing the float data type functionality, which provides 64 bits of binary precision and can represent up to 17 decimal places, is generally sufficient for most applications. We have also developed functions that utilize the DECFLOAT34 data type, offering 128 bits of precision. This level of precision exceeds what is readily available in most other programming languages. Yet, it integrates well within the ABAP type system, and some users might benefit from 128 bits of precision or larger numbers. Often, it is more relevant to support higher exponents than more digits of precision. 
 

3. Simple combinatoric functions: factorial( ) and binomial( )

 

The first two functions covered in this article are used for combinatorics. These are very basic and occur in a wide variety of settings. These are the factorial and binomial functions. Both take integer arguments and deliver a float or decfloat34 value. As factorials can be pretty large, the extended precision of decfloat34 is beneficial here. 
 
Both functions return integers mathematically, but in ABAP, they return F and DECFLOAT34 to support a wider range of input parameters. 
 

a) Factorial

Description: Describes the number of ways in which n items can be ordered. Written n!.

Good to know: available in Microsoft Excel as FACT( ) 
 
This function appears in a wide variety of settings.
 
So if we have Apple and Banana (two items), the factorial is also 2, as there are two possible orderings (Apple, Banana) and (Banana, Apple). For three items, Apple, Banana, and Orange, we have six orderings (Apple, Banana, Orange), (Apple, Orange, Banana), (Orange, Apple, Banana), (Orange, Banana, Apple), (Banana, Orange, Apple), (Banana, Apple, Orange).
 
The factorial has a simple formula:
n! = n*(n-1)*(n-2)*...*1
For the first position, we have n possibilities to choose an item, for the second position only n-1, and so on.
 
Factorials can be pretty large. For example:
50! = 30414093201713378043612608166064768844377641568960512000000000000
The ABAP kernel computes the factorials using a precomputed table for small values and the transcendental gamma function for large values. This is much faster than computing n * (n-1) * ... * 1.
 
Here is the ABAP example:
 
data large type decfloat34.
large = factorial( 1000 ).
cl_demo_output=>display( large ).
ABAP correctly outputs: 4.023872600770937735437024339230040E+2567.
 

b.) Binomial coefficient

Description: Describes the number of ways in which k items can be chosen out of a total set of n items. Written C(n, k).

Good to know: available in Microsoft Excel as COMBIN( ) 
 
For example, C(5,1) equals 5, as there are five possibilities for choosing one item out of five. C(4,2) equals six, as if you have four items (1,2,3,4), you have the six possibilities {1,2}, {1,3}, {1,4}, {2,4}, {2,4}, and {3,4} to choose 2 items. Note here that the ordering is not considered, i.e., the binomial coefficient is not the number of ways to choose an ordered set of k items out of n items.
 
There is a simple formula for the binomial coefficient as well:
C(n,k) = n! / ( k! * (n-k)! )

Here is a simple ABAP program to use the function:

data large type decfloat34.
large = binomial( n = 20000 k = 5000 ).
cl_demo_output=>display( large ).

This correctly outputs: 1.566362779957802233492978893365436E+4882, as you have many options to choose from, 5000 items out of 20,000 items.

Note that the binomial coefficient is typically not computed by the above formula, but by the transcendental beta function. This is also done in ABAP.

4. Basic transcendental functions: gamma( ) and log_gamma( )

These basic transcendental functions appear everywhere in statistics, probability theory, and many other settings. If you don't know them, imagine them as similar to transcendental functions like sin(x), cos(x), and log(x).

The importance of the gamma function comes from the fact that it is defined on the whole range of real numbers (except -1, -2, ...) and that for positive integers n:

n! = Gamma(n+1)

The gamma function is defined as an integral (for positive real numbers) as:

It is essential, as it defines the probability density of the gamma probability distribution and some other probability distributions. Thus, it is often used in statistics.

As the gamma function grows rapidly, in practice, the function log_gamma(x) is often used, which is defined as:

log_gamma(x) = log(abs(gamma(x))

The computation of the log_gamma function is also more numerically stable. 

Here is a picture of both functions:

The usage in ABAP is simple:

 data gamma_value type decfloat34.
 data log_gamma_value type decfloat34.
 data test_log_gamma type decfloat34.
 
 gamma_value = gamma( - 1 / 2 ).
 log_gamma_value = log_gamma( - 1 / 2 ).
 test_log_gamma = log( abs( gamma( -1 / 2 ) ) ).
 
 assert log_gamma_value = test_log_gamma.
 
 cl_demo_output=>write( gamma_value ).
 cl_demo_output=>write( log_gamma_value ).
 cl_demo_output=>write( test_log_gamma ).
 cl_demo_output=>display( ).

This correctly outputs:

GAMMA_VALUE
-3.544907701811032054596334966682290

LOG_GAMMA_VALUE
1.265512123484645396488945797134706

TEST_LOG_GAMMA
1.265512123484645396488945797134706

Good to know: These functions are available in Microsoft Excel as GAMMA( ) and GAMMALN( ).

5. Statistic functions: erf( ), erf_inv(), erfc(), erfc_inv()

The error function is another fundamental transcendental function. The importance of the error function erf(x) comes from the fact that it is related to the distribution function of the normal probability distribution.

The area marked in yellow below the blue curve (which draws the probability density function of the standard normal distribution) is given by:

The yellow area gives the probability that an event is smaller than or equal to some given value. 

An integral again defines the error function:

Good to know: The error function is available in Microsoft Excel as ERF().

The graph of the function erf(x) is simple:

As you can see from the graph, the error function is invertible on the interval (-1,1). The inverse function is called erf_inv(x) and is used to compute the quantile of the normal distribution. The graph of the inverse function looks like so:

Good to know: The inverse error function is available in Microsoft Excel as ERFINV()

In addition to the error and inverse error functions, there are the complementary error functions erfc(x) and inverse erfc_inv(x). The complementary error function is defined as:

 Why is this function needed? There are multiple reasons this function is used very often, as it appears naturally in statistics, but is also needed numerically to compute probabilities very close to 1, where erf(x) loses precision (floating point numbers are very precise around 0 and not very precise around 1).

Good to know: The complementary error function is called ERFC() in Microsoft Excel.

Here is a basic usage in ABAP:

 final(erf) = erf( 1 / 2 ).
 final(erfc) = erfc( 1 / 2 ).
 final(erf_inv) = erf_inv( 1 / 2 ).

 cl_demo_output=>write( erf ).
 cl_demo_output=>write( erfc ).
 cl_demo_output=>write( erf_inv ).
 cl_demo_output=>display( ).

6. Conclusion

This article introduced 8 new mathematical functions in ABAP for the ABAP environments for 2508. These can be applied in a business context in statistical applications. A good example for this can be found in the following blog post:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/random-numbers-and-probability-distributio...

entry.title: Certification as a Catalyst: How Minsait Drives SAP Excellence in Brazil
entry.content:
Our partner Minsait, a company of the Indra Group, has established itself as a benchmark in digital transformation and SAP operations in Brazil. In this exclusive interview, the company shares how its long-standing commitment to SAP certifications has shaped its strategy, strengthened customer trust, and positioned it uniquely in the market. From pioneering SAP BTP operations in Brazil to driving innovation with AI, sustainability, and data-driven solutions, Minsait explains how it helps customers unlock the full potential of the SAP ecosystem — and what strategic priorities will guide the next chapter of its growth. We highly appreciate our enduring collaboration with Minsait and their openness in sharing valuable insights and experiences as a trusted SAP-certified operations partner.

 

Would you like to start by telling us about your company and the services MINSAIT offers?

Minsait, a company of the Indra Group, is a leader in new digital environments and disruptive technologies, with a global presence and strong operations in Brazil. Our portfolio covers everything from strategic consulting to the implementation and management of mission-critical solutions, with a focus on delivering tangible business results. We operate across the entire value chain, offering consulting, systems integration, custom development, cybersecurity, automation, artificial intelligence, and application management services.

In the SAP ecosystem, we support companies through end-to-end journeys — from defining the strategy, implementing digital transformation projects, migrating to SAP S/4HANA, and operating complex environments, to leveraging innovations such as SAP BTP, AI, Industry 4.0, and sustainability.

 

Minsati joined the certification program for operations partner in 2010 - what was the deciding factor behind this decision?

From the beginning, we understood that SAP certification was not just a label, but a competitive differentiator to reinforce our customers’ trust. By joining the program in 2010, our goal was to prove — with SAP’s endorsement — the quality and maturity of our SAP operations and support processes. The certification was also seen as a public commitment to global best practices, aligning our operations with the highest standards in the market.

To what extent has this certification been helpful in your marketing efforts and in your communication with customers?

The certification is a powerful tool in building credibility. In the sales process, it serves as concrete proof that we follow SAP-recognized standards and have proven capabilities to deliver high-quality services. It also differentiates Minsait in competitive bids and RFPs, strengthening our position as a trusted partner for strategic projects and mission-critical operations.

  

MINSAIT has recently received certification for SAP BTP operations in Brazil for the first time. What significance does SAP BTP hold for MINSAIT and its customers? And to what extent did the audit support your SAP BTP strategy?

SAP BTP is far more than a technical platform — it is a central pillar of our digital transformation strategy for customers. It enables us to create extensions, intelligent integrations, automations, and advanced data and analytics solutions, enhancing the value of the SAP core while keeping it clean (clean core). In practice, this means transforming ERP systems into intelligent, scalable platforms ready for continuous innovation.

The importance of this achievement is even greater because Minsait is only the second company in Brazil to obtain the SAP BTP operations certification. This reinforces our position as a trusted partner frequently recommended to support customers in complex and strategic BTP projects. This trust is no coincidence — it is the result of a solid track record of more than 180 SAP BTP developments and success stories, covering integration, automation, extension, and analytics scenarios for clients across various industries.

When combined with other high-profile certifications such as CMMI, TMMi, SAP BTP Operations, and SAP S/4HANA Solutions Operations, this achievement places Minsait in a unique position: we are the only Brazilian company with this set of certifications, demonstrating our unmatched strength in development quality, testing, and SAP operations management.

The audit played a key role in further strengthening our BTP strategy. It validated practices, highlighted our strengths, and pointed to areas for improvement — such as test automation, observability, and standardization of operations across multiple environments. We have incorporated these recommendations into our roadmap, enabling us to further raise our maturity level and ensure every BTP delivery is a benchmark for quality and innovation in the market.

 

Minsait and SAP team at the audit in July 2025

 

SAP consistently aligns its strategy with the cloud and encourages partners to actively support customers during their migration journey. What distinguishes your company in this regard, and how do you support your customers in their digital transformation?

Our differentiator lies in the combination of experience, proximity to our customers’ business, and multidisciplinary technical expertise. We work with agile methodologies, proprietary tools, and accelerators that reduce project time and migration risks. Furthermore, we don’t just migrate systems to the cloud — we ensure that this move delivers real business value, integrating data, artificial intelligence, automation, and clean core practices.

This consultative, results-oriented approach enables us to accelerate SAP innovation adoption, ensuring that each customer gets the most from their cloud investment.

 

How do your SAP certifications reflect your strategy and position in the Brazilian market?

The achievement of SAP BTP Operations certification in Brazil, along with the renewal of our SAP S/4HANA Solutions Operations certification, is not just a technical milestone — it is a symbol of our continuous evolution and the trust we have earned from SAP and our customers.

Since joining the certification program in 2010, our strategy has been clear: align our processes with the most demanding global standards while maintaining the agility and proximity required by the Brazilian market. Over the years, this approach has established us as a reference in SAP application management and the execution of high-complexity projects, always focusing on quality, security, and business results.

The fact that we are the only Brazilian company to hold certifications such as CMMI, TMMi, and the certifications for SAP BTP operations and SAP S/4HANA solutions Operations reinforces our robustness and organizational maturity. This allows us to consistently deliver value, whether in complex implementations, cloud migrations, critical integrations, or the ongoing management of mission-critical environments.

Our commitment for the coming years is to continue innovating, anticipating trends, and helping our customers get the most out of the SAP ecosystem — always with the security of having a certified, experienced, and results-driven partner.

 

Looking ahead, what are your strategic priorities in your partnership with SAP? Are there specific areas within SAP’s portfolio – such as AI, sustainability, industry cloud, or further expansion in SAP BTP – where you see growth opportunities or plan to invest?

Our strategic priorities are focused on six major pillars:

First, we are expanding our SAP BTP expertise, using it as a platform for innovation, automation, and seamless data integration. We are also applying Artificial Intelligence directly to business processes, leveraging SAP AI Core and AI Hub capabilities as well as partnerships with leading technology providers. Sustainability and ESG are deeply embedded in our portfolio, with solutions that enable customers to measure, reduce, and report their environmental and social impact. At the same time, we support the responsible and fast adoption of SAP S/4HANA, ensuring that customers who have not yet migrated can make the transition securely and with clear added value. Another key focus is the Business Data Cloud (BDC), which reinforces our commitment to transforming our customers’ data into strategic and monetizable assets. Finally, through Intelligent AMS, we combine advanced monitoring, automation, and predictive analytics to reduce incidents and maximize performance.

 

Information on the certification program for operations partners and an overview of all certified partners can be found in the SAP Operations Partner Guide.

Visit OPC at SAP.com

entry.title: Rework Process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Process Manufacturing with Co-Products and Scrap
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I’m currently working on an SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition implementation in the area of process manufacturing, and I would like to ask for your insights regarding the rework process.

Here is my scenario:

  • I produce a finished product (FG) using a BOM that includes co-products (products manufactured simultaneously with the FG) and scrap.

  • At the end of production, I decide that the finished product is not conforming.

  • I want to run a rework process, where:

    • The input is the nonconforming finished product.

    • The output is a conforming portion of the finished product, the co-product, and the associated scrap.

My question:
How can I model and execute this rework process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for process manufacturing (not discrete manufacturing)?

  • Are there standard steps I should follow?

  • Which Fiori apps should I use (for order creation, confirmation, rework , etc.)?

  • Is there a recommended best practice for managing this scenario (e.g., using a rework recipe, process order adjustments, or another approach)?

Any guidance, experience sharing, or references to official documentation would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your support!

entry.title: Geographical dimensions and hierarchies in new SAC datamodels
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am simply looking to understand them when importing a local Excel file for now.

My main interrogation is about the geographical dimensions. With the classic model, you simply had to click the icon 'Geo enrichment', then choose Coordinates or Area Name, then select the corresponding columns, and you basically had your geographical dimension.

In the new model, the only way I found to do this is by adding the properties 'Latitude' and 'Longitude', to the dimension, which automatically creates a dimension table, and transforms it into a valid geographical dimension.

The first question : Is that the only way to do it in the new type of model ?

So now I have my cities geo enriched with the coordinates, but I would like to add a hierarchy on top of that, to maybe be able to dig in a geo map. (Go from continent, to country, to city for instance)

I can't figure out how to do this right now, do I have to create the hierarchy before ? But then I can't create the dimension table necessary for the coordinates.

My second question would be : Is it possible to have a geographical dimension with a level-hierarchy in the new models ?

I am just trying to make sure I did not miss some new functionnality.

Have a great day !

entry.title: Security related ATC checks, nonsense of pseudo comments
entry.content:
Hi all,

I want to use ATC security checks to identify certain security vulnerables like usage of GENERATE REPORT, GENERATE SUBROUINE POOL and others. I found there are already ATC checks available for, but they can be easily suppressed by pseudo comment

"#EC CI_GENERATE.

In my opinion, it absolutely makes no sense to be able supress certain ATC checks by pseudo comments. In some cases it makes sense (like BAPI call with material length check). But for security related topics, it is dangerous in my opinion. Instead, ATC exemption should be used for this imo.

If you employ unfriendly/enemy developers (i.e., by external partner), they simply add pseudo comments to cheat on ATC check. This makes it more challenging in identifying vulnerable code as I can't trust ATC checks here.

Is there a way to overcome this issue (beside replacing developers)

entry.title: Re: BDCQ - Finance - Needs to be in sync with SAP Best Pr...
entry.content:
Hello @KP_2025 

Gathering Responses in the Business Driven Configuration Questionnaire can be challenging, but this SAP Learning Gathering Responses in the Business Driven Configuration Questionnaire (BDCQ) Will be very helpful

The BDCQ helps collect configuration values that you will later enter into SAP Central Business Configuration.

Within BDCQ, configuration experts utilise the Scope Reference (scope item ID) from the DDA to filter relevant business processes. This is done with L2 questions prior to Fit-to-Standard and L3 questions during workshops, confirming that scope item IDs are the key link for mapping requirements.  You can refer to the SAP Learning link above

What are the best practices for SAP S/4HANA Cloud in the Finance Line of Business? There are subgroups, such as Accounting & Financial Close, Advanced Financial Operations, and Enterprise Risk & Compliance, among others. Scope items fall under these. SAP Press Blog

Let me know if you need further information.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: BYD2508 Remove old partner contanct
entry.content:
Hi Community,

In SAP Business By Design, direct removal of a partner contact is not supported in the system UI, as this data is centrally managed with your subscription.

As outlined in KBA 3017227 – Removal of SAP Partner Contact, such requests are not handled by SAP Product Support. Please contact your SAP Account Manager, Customer Engagement Executive (CEE), or Customer Success Manager (CSM) to perform this change.

These roles are responsible for assisting with customer master data and subscription-related activities.

We appreciate your understanding and cooperation. If you have any further questions, please feel free to reach out — we are happy to help.

 

Kind regards,

Arpita Joshi

SAP Product Support

Community:

SAP Business ByDesign:https://www.sap.com/community/topics/business-bydesign.html

entry.title: Re: I can see application job template but not able to se...
entry.content:
Hello,

I had this same issue a while ago. Every time you create an Application Job Template, an IAM App with the suffix _SAJC is automatically created.

What you need to do is create a Business Catalog and associate this app with it, in eclipse ADT. Then, go to your S/4HANA instance and associate this business catalog with a Business Role that your user has.

After that, you should be able to run it.

Kind Regards,

Marcelo Romeiro

entry.title: Re: Cannot create support case for SFSF cloud system
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

The following KBA contains the necessary authorizations for creating or viewing support cases for SFSF systems in SAP for Me.

2193754 S-user is unable to create or view SuccessFactors support cases - SAP for Me

In case of missing authorizations, the affected system cannot be selected.

If your S-User has any of the mentioned authorizations on INSTALL level, check the installation number of the system which is missing. In such a case you need the authorizations assigned for the affected installation number as well.

Example:

there are the following SFSF installations under customer number X:

instA

SFSFsystemA1

SFSFsystemA2

instB

SFSFsystemB1

SFSFsystemB2

instC

SFSFsystemC1

If an S-User has the authorizations on INSTALL level for instA and instB, but not for instC, the user will not be able to see system "SFSFsystemC1" upon opening a case.

In order to gain the necessary authorization, kindly reach out to your Cloud Admin or request them in SAP for Me as described here:

2891528 How to use the Self-Service Authorization Request - SAP for Me

Kind regards,

SAP Support
